headline.seo: Human Microbiome Project Explores Our 100 Trillion Good Bacteria
headline.print_headline: In Good Health? Thank Your 100 Trillion Bacteria
headline.main: In Good Health? Thank Your 100 Trillion Bacteria

docs.abstract: Human Microbiome Project publishes the results of its five-year endeavor in journal Nature and three PLoS journals; research finds that human beings contain thousands of diverse bacterial strains that live largely peaceful lives within their hosts; project involved the sequencing of genetic material of bacteria from nearly 250 healthy people.
docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists discovered that every human body has a unique health-promoting team of up to a thousand kinds of microbes.
docs.snippet: Scientists discovered that every human body has a unique health-promoting team of up to a thousand kinds of microbes.

headline.main: Narrow Majority of City Voters Oppose Mayor's Soda Plan, Poll Finds

docs.abstract: Quinnipiac University poll shows that a narrow majority of New York City voters oppose Mayor Michael R Bloomberg's plan to restrict sales of large sugary beverages in city restaurants, movie theaters and street carts. (M).
docs.lead_paragraph: A narrow majority of New York City voters oppose Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to restrict sales of big sugary beverages in city restaurants, movie theaters and street carts, according to a poll released on Wednesday. Opponents of the plan edged out supporters, 51 percent to 46 percent; opposition was strongest among older voters, white voters and voters on Staten Island. The poll, conducted by Quinnipiac University, found voters divided along political, educational and geographic lines over the proposal, which has attracted international interest and could become a major landmark of Mr. Bloomberg's public health initiatives.
docs.snippet: A narrow majority of New York City voters oppose Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to restrict sales of big sugary beverages in city restaurants, movie theaters and street carts, according to a poll released on Wednesday. Opponents of the plan edged...

headline.print_headline: Narrow Majority of City Voters Oppose Mayor’s Soda Plan, Poll Finds
headline.main: Slight Majority of New Yorkers Oppose Soda Ban

docs.abstract: Opposition to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to restrict sales of big sugary beverages was strongest among older voters, white voters and voters on Staten Island.
docs.snippet: Opposition to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to restrict sales of big sugary beverages was strongest among older voters, white voters and voters on Staten Island.

headline.seo: At Starbucks, Uncertainty Over Mayor’s Drink Plan
headline.print_headline: At Starbucks, Uncertainty Over Impact of Bloomberg’s Drink Plan
headline.main: At Starbucks, Uncertainty Over Impact of Bloomberg’s Drink Plan

docs.abstract: New York City's Board of Health has yet to determine how Mayor Michael R Bloomberg's plan to restrict sales of large-size sugary drinks in New York City will impact Starbucks; plan exempts any beverage that is more than 50 percent milk by volume, but Starbucks offerings are complicated because they are customized and amount of ice, milk and sugar can vary with each order.
docs.lead_paragraph: Company officials said they were unsure how Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan to ban sales of big sugary drinks might jibe with the milkshake-style coffee drinks that are popular at their stores.
docs.snippet: Company officials said they were unsure how Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan to ban sales of big sugary drinks might jibe with the milkshake-style coffee drinks that are popular at their stores.

headline.seo: Persistent Obesity Fuels Soda Ban by Bloomberg
headline.print_headline: Obesity Ills That Won’t Budge Fuel Soda Battle by Bloomberg
headline.main: Obesity Ills That Won’t Budge Fuel Soda Battle by Bloomberg

docs.abstract: Tally of overweight and obese New Yorkers continues to grow faster in the Bronx than anywhere else in New York City, despite Mayor Michael R Bloomberg's aggressive anti-obesity efforts, including a controversial proposal to ban super-sized and sugary drinks; nearly one in every three Bronx adults is obese, a sign that education efforts and access to healthier foods may not be enough.
docs.lead_paragraph: Intractable obesity rates in areas like the Bronx suggest that New York City’s previous efforts have not been enough to change behaviors.
docs.snippet: Intractable obesity rates in areas like the Bronx suggest that New York City’s previous efforts have not been enough to change behaviors.

headline.main: What We Eat: Doubts by the Teaspoonful

docs.abstract: Americans consume $1.5 billion in artificial sweeteners every year, but their use is often accompanied by lingering health concerns; decades of research has been inconclusive about sweetener safety, and consumer choices continue to be guided by whimsy rather than scientific fact (Series: What We Eat). Photo, Drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: White. Pink. Blue. Yellow. On restaurant tables everywhere, the colors of the sweetener packets instantly identify the contents.
docs.snippet: White. Pink. Blue. Yellow.     On restaurant tables everywhere, the colors of the sweetener packets instantly identify the contents.

headline.print_headline: What We Eat: Doubts by the Teaspoonful

docs.abstract: Despite decades of use and tests, many people have lingering concerns about the safety of the options available - mainly saccharin, aspartame and sucralose - with choices often based on hearsay, mythology and whim.
docs.snippet: Despite decades of use and tests, many people have lingering concerns about the safety of the options available - mainly saccharin, aspartame and sucralose - with choices often based on hearsay, mythology and whim.
